Award.AwardTitle: SCIART: Bioanalytical Technology for Art: Immunological Techniques for the Identification of Proteins and Polysaccharides in Art, Archaeological and Ethnographic Objects
Award.AbstractNarration:
With support from the Chemical Measurement and Imaging program, Julie Arslanoglu of New York's Metropolitan Museum, of Art and John Loike of Columbia University seek to develop and improve methodologies such as enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay (ELISA) for the detection, identification, and localization of proteins and gums in art. Identification of these diverse biological materials (found in paints, coatings, and adhesives) will improve understanding essential for informed treatment, preservation, and authentication. The approaches developed will improve specificity in identification, enabling for example distinction between use of whole egg or only egg white as a gilding adhesive, or the use of sturgeon?s glue or goat?s milk explicitly as a paint binder. Parallel mass spectrometric studies should enable identification of specific targets for improved characterization, and aptamer technology is being used to identify organic molecules in art. The complementary nature of these techniques is being explored. Finally, the localization of proteins and polysaccharide in paint or coating layers in cross-sections is being characterized using Surface Enhanced Raman (SERS)-labeled antibodies. This will greatly enhance knowledge of an artist?s technique as well as conservation treatment.

In addition to important insights into the preservation and authentication of cultural heritage objects, methods developed in these studies should contribute to other fields affected by similar limitations (low concentration of highly degraded organic materials with interfering inorganic ions), such as environmental monitoring or forensic analysis. The research entails teaching and training of students and postdocs interested in the science of preservation of cultural heritage. Results will be widely disseminated to the general public through websites and presentations in the museum setting, as well as scholarly conferences and publications.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Proteins and polysaccharides come from living systems; however, they also are used as materials to create artworks (Figure 1). The correct identification of these materials is important for both the preservation of artworks and to understand how an object was created. The proteins and gums come from natural sources such as animal skins, fish bladders, eggs, milk, and plant exudates, and therefore are mixtures of compounds. Once mixed with pigments, dried and aged, changes occur within the molecules and the accurate identification of protein and gum sources becomes difficult. When we couple this challenge with the very limited sample permitted from priceless artworks (less than the size of the period at the end of this sentence), the current typical technologies for protein and gum identification in artworks can be unsuccessful.

In order to address the need for accessible methods, this project drew upon biological techniques and created a reliable and sensitive test for detecting and identifying the most common proteins and gums found in artworks using the enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay (ELISA). Furthermore, we demonstrated that while age significantly impacts the amount of material extracted from a paint sample, it is the pigment type that has a greater effect on the success of the assay (Figure 2). The ELISA response is likely to be most impacted by pigment interactions that cause the three-dimensional structure of the protein to change as well as chemical modifications to individual amino acids. Unraveling which modifications interfere with antibody recognition as well as identifying the parts of the protein that remain recognizable despite age or pigment type is extremely complex. Therefore, we began mass spectrometric studies in order to identify conserved and modified peptides that may account for the observed changes in ELISA response. And finally, we were the first to establish a modification of the ELISA technique for the simultaneous identification and localization of proteins in cross-sections of samples taken from artworks containing multiple layers. We did this by directly applying antibodies coupled to a SERS-nanoparticle reporting system to the cross-section surface (Figure 3). The power of this technique is that it can identify both which protein is present and in what layer it occurs. Our initial research also demonstrated the importance of developing new particles that do not randomly adhere to each other or to the paint surface.

Immunological techniques applied to the study of cultural heritage offer the potential for a fast, reliable, and sensitive protein and gum analytical technique without requiring relatively expensive equipment. With this ability, more cultural institutions can provide specific and accurate protein and gum identification, ultimately enriching our knowledge about artworks and improving their preservation.
